description: From Middle English sak (‚Äúbag, sackcloth‚Äù), from Old English sacc (‚Äúsack, bag‚Äù) and s√¶cc (‚Äúsackcloth, sacking‚Äù); both from Proto-West Germanic *sakku, from late Proto-Germanic *sakkuz (‚Äúsack‚Äù), borrowed from Latin saccus (‚Äúlarge bag‚Äù), from Ancient Greek œÉŒ¨Œ∫Œ∫ŒøœÇ (s√°kkos, ‚Äúbag of coarse cloth‚Äù), from Semitic, possibly Phoenician or Hebrew.

Cognate with Dutch zak, German Sack, Swedish s√§ck, Danish s√¶k, Hebrew ◊©÷∑◊Ç◊ß‚Äé (≈õaq, ‚Äúsack, sackcloth‚Äù), Aramaic ◊°÷∑◊ß÷∏÷º◊ê‚Äé, Classical Syriac ‹£‹©‹ê‚Äé, Ge'ez ·à†·âÖ (≈õ√§·∏≥), Akkadian íÜ≠íäì (saqqu), Egyptian sÍú£gÍú£. Doublet of sac, saccus, saco, and sakkos.

ƒåern√Ω and Forbes suggest the word was originally Egyptian, a nominal derivative of sÍú£q (‚Äúto gather or put together‚Äù) that also yielded Coptic ‚≤•‚≤ü‚≤ï (sok, ‚Äúsackcloth‚Äù) and was borrowed into Greek perhaps by way of a Semitic intermediary. However, Vycichl and Hoch reject this idea, noting that such an originally Egyptian word would be expected to yield Hebrew *◊°÷∑◊ß rather than ◊©÷∑◊Ç◊ß‚Äé. Instead, they posit that the Coptic and Greek words are both borrowed from Semitic, with the Coptic word perhaps developing via Egyptian sÍú£gÍú£.

entries.meaning: A bag; especially a large bag of strong, coarse material for storage and handling of various commodities, such as potatoes, coal, coffee; or, a bag with handles used at a supermarket, a grocery sack; or, a small bag for small items, a satchel.

The amount a sack holds; also, an archaic or historical measure of varying capacity, depending on commodity type and according to local usage; an old English measure of weight, usually of wool, equal to 13 stone (182 pounds), or in other sources, 26 stone (364 pounds).
examples: Seven pounds make a clove, 2 cloves a stone, 2 stone a tod, 6 1/2 tods a wey, 2 weys a sack, 12 sacks a last. [...] It is to be observed here that a sack is 13 tods, and a tod 28 pounds, so that the sack is 364 pounds.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The plunder and pillaging of a captured town or city.
(uncountable) Loot or booty obtained by pillage.
(American football) A successful tackle of the quarterback behind the line of scrimmage. See verb sense4 below.
(baseball) One of the square bases anchored at first base, second base, or third base.
examples: He twisted his ankle sliding into the sack at second.

entries.meaning: (informal) Dismissal from employment, or discharge from a position, usually as give (someone) the sack or get the sack. See verb sense5 below.
examples: The boss is gonna give her the sack today.
He got the sack for being late all the time.

entries.meaning: (colloquial, US) Bed (either literally or figuratively); usually as hit the sack or in the sack. See also sack out.

(dated) (also sacque) A kind of loose-fitting gown or dress with sleeves which hangs from the shoulders, such as a gown with a Watteau back or sack-back, fashionable in the late 17th to 18th century; or, formerly, a loose-fitting hip-length jacket, cloak or cape.
examples: Her Dress, too, was of the same cast, a thin muslin short sacque and Coat lined throughout with Pink, ‚Äì a modesty bit ‚Äì and something of a very short cloak half concealed about half of her old wrinkled Neck [‚Ä¶].

entries.meaning: (dated) A sack coat; a kind of coat worn by men, and extending from top to bottom without a cross seam.
(vulgar, slang) The scrotum.
examples: He got passed the ball, but it hit him in the sack.

verbs.description: sack (third-person singular simple present sacks, present participle sacking, simple past and past participle sacked)

entries.meaning: To put in a sack or sacks.
To bear or carry in a sack upon the back or the shoulders.
To plunder or pillage, especially after capture; to obtain spoils of war from.
examples: The barbarians sacked Rome in 410 CE.

entries.meaning: (American football) To tackle the quarterback behind the line of scrimmage, especially before he is able to throw a pass.
examples: On third down, the rejuvenated Rickey Jackson stormed in over All-Pro left tackle Richmond Webb to sack Marino yet again for a 2-yard loss.

entries.meaning: (informal, transitive) To discharge from a job or position; to fire.

description: From earlier (wyne) seck from Middle French (vin (‚Äúwine‚Äù)) sec (‚Äúdry‚Äù), from Latin siccus (‚Äúdry‚Äù).

entries.meaning: (dated) A variety of light-colored dry wine from Spain or the Canary Islands; also, any strong white wine from southern Europe; sherry.
examples: The vesper bell had rung its parting note; the domini were mostly caged in comfortable quarters, discussing the merits of old port; and the merry student had closed his oak, to consecrate the night to friendship, sack, and claret.

entries.meaning: Dated form of sac (‚Äúpouch in a plant or animal‚Äù).
examples: Sometimes fishes are born that have rudimentary yolk sacks. Such young are born prematurely.

entries.meaning: Alternative spelling of sac (‚Äúsacrifice‚Äù)

verbs.description: sack (third-person singular simple present sacks, present participle sacking, simple past and past participle sacked)

entries.meaning: Alternative spelling of sac (‚Äúsacrifice‚Äù)
